title: Fluctuating DNA methylation tracks cancer evolution at clinical scale
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09374-4

Cancer evolutionary dynamics are quantitatively inferred using a method, EVOFLUx, applied to fluctuating DNA methylation.
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09374-4 Cancer evolutionary dynamics are quantitatively inferred using a method, EVOFLUx, applied to fluctuating DNA methylation.

title: Loss-of-function mutations in PLD4 lead to systemic lupus erythematosus
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09513-x

PLD4 loss-of-function mutations in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus leads to excessive activation of TLR7 and TLR9.
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09513-x PLD4 loss-of-function mutations in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus leads to excessive activation of TLR7 and TLR9.

title: Amplifying antigen-induced cellular responses with proximity labelling
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09518-6

Red light- or ultrasound-controlled proximity labelling is engineered to stimulate clustering-induced receptor activation and downstream signalling ampl…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09518-6 Red light- or ultrasound-controlled proximity labelling is engineered to stimulate clustering-induced receptor activation and downstream signalling amplification to promote antitumour immune responses.

title: Neuronal activity-dependent mechanisms of small cell lung cancer pathogenesis
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09492-z

Glutamatergic and GABAergic (γ-aminobutyric acid-producing) cortical neuronal activity drives proliferation of small lung cell cancer via paracrine inte…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09492-z Glutamatergic and GABAergic (γ-aminobutyric acid-producing) cortical neuronal activity drives proliferation of small lung cell cancer via paracrine interactions and through synapses formed with tumour cells.

title: Molecular subtypes of human skeletal muscle in cancer cachexia
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09502-0

Unbiased clustering analysis of the skeletal muscle RNAome in patients with cancer identifies two molecular subtypes, one of which distinguishes individ…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09502-0 Unbiased clustering analysis of the skeletal muscle RNAome in patients with cancer identifies two molecular subtypes, one of which distinguishes individuals with cachexia and indicates potential target pathways for future research.

title: Observing differential spin currents by resonant inelastic X-ray scattering
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09488-9

Resonant inelastic X-ray scattering can be used to measure the spin current carried by magnons in the presence of temperature gradients across a magneti…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09488-9 Resonant inelastic X-ray scattering can be used to measure the spin current carried by magnons in the presence of temperature gradients across a magnetic insulator.

title: Energy deficiency selects crowded live epithelial cells for extrusion
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09514-w

Crowded epithelial cells with the least energy and membrane potential are selected for extrusion.
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09514-w Crowded epithelial cells with the least energy and membrane potential are selected for extrusion.

title: Systematic attribution of heatwaves to the emissions of carbon majors
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09450-9

Climate change made 213 historical heatwaves reported over 2000–2023 more likely and more intense, to which each of the 180 carbon majors (fossil fuel a…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09450-9 Climate change made 213 historical heatwaves reported over 2000–2023 more likely and more intense, to which each of the 180 carbon majors (fossil fuel and cement producers) substantially contributed.

title: Redox-driven mineral and organic associations in Jezero Crater, Mars
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09413-0

A geological, petrographic and geochemical survey of distinctive mudstone and conglomerate outcrops of the Bright Angel formation on Mars reveals textur…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09413-0 A geological, petrographic and geochemical survey of distinctive mudstone and conglomerate outcrops of the Bright Angel formation on Mars reveals textures, chemical and mineral characteristics, and organic signatures that warrant consideration as potential biosignatures.

title: Myeloid progenitor dysregulation fuels immunosuppressive macrophages in tumours
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09493-y

An understanding of the molecular mechanisms promoting the generation of immunoregulatory and tumour-promoting monocytes and macrophages is key to break…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09493-y An understanding of the molecular mechanisms promoting the generation of immunoregulatory and tumour-promoting monocytes and macrophages is key to breaking the cycle of tumour myelopoiesis and developing more effective myeloid-targeting therapies.

title: Probing the heterogeneous nature of LiF in solid–electrolyte interphases
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09498-7

Using 19F nuclear magnetic resonance to study LiF–LiH solid solutions revealed that it is present in the solid–electrolyte interphase of lithium metal b…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09498-7 Using 19F nuclear magnetic resonance to study LiF–LiH solid solutions revealed that it is present in the solid–electrolyte interphase of lithium metal batteries and confirms the heterogeneous nature of LiF in such interphases.

title: Functional synapses between neurons and small cell lung cancer
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09434-9

Small cell lung cancer cells form functional synapses with glutamatergic neurons, receiving synaptic transmissions and deriving a proliferative advantag…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09434-9 Small cell lung cancer cells form functional synapses with glutamatergic neurons, receiving synaptic transmissions and deriving a proliferative advantage from these interactions.

title: Probing non-equilibrium topological order on a quantum processor
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09456-3

A superconducting quantum computer is used to realize an out-of-equilibrium topologically ordered state, which hosts anyonic excitations.
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09456-3 A superconducting quantum computer is used to realize an out-of-equilibrium topologically ordered state, which hosts anyonic excitations.

title: Probing the Kitaev honeycomb model on a neutral-atom quantum computer
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09475-0

Digital quantum simulations of Kitaev’s honeycomb model are realized for two-dimensional fermionic systems using a reconfigurable atom-array processor a…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09475-0 Digital quantum simulations of Kitaev’s honeycomb model are realized for two-dimensional fermionic systems using a reconfigurable atom-array processor and used to study the Fermi–Hubbard model on a square lattice.

title: Heatwaves linked to carbon emissions from specific companies
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02915-x

Nearly one-quarter of heatwaves would have been ‘virtually impossible’ without global warming — and can be attributed to the emissions of individual ene…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02915-x Nearly one-quarter of heatwaves would have been ‘virtually impossible’ without global warming — and can be attributed to the emissions of individual energy producers.

title: Iron-respiring microbes could have a role in sulfur cycling
summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02861-8

A bacterium that uses sulfide as an energy source to metabolize solid iron oxides has been discovered, revealing a biological reaction that was previous…
body: Nature, Published online: 10 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02861-8 A bacterium that uses sulfide as an energy source to metabolize solid iron oxides has been discovered, revealing a biological reaction that was previously assumed to be solely chemical. This finding uncovers a firm microbial link between sulfur and iron cycling in oxygen-free environments such as aquatic sediments.

title: 'He is an awful man': Why we are wrong about Darcy
summary: Miserable and 'cruel', Jane Austen's romantic hero is not what he seems

title: How Goodfellas reinvented the gangster film
summary: Martin Scorsese's crime epic was released 35 years ago

title: Muscly Sydney Sweeney can't fix 'clichéd' Christy
summary: Actress is unconvincing as a champion boxer, despite dramatic transformation
